message.content: The term "PR complete" or "all PRs out by" refers to the date by which all pull requests intended to be part of a release should be functionally complete and out for review. It's acceptable if these pull requests still require a few updates, but the expectation is that any pending PRs will conclude within a business day or two. This date is tracked in the sprints and is a critical milestone in the release planning process [doc1].

citations.content:
AI Cognitive Services SDK Releases

  • "When's the next release?"
  • "How long is there left to get this change in?"
  • "When did we release that old version?"

Current, in-development release

Sprint Label Version - Speech Version - Vision All PRs out Release by Notes
202301 1.25.0 0.7 Fri Jan 13 Fri Jan 27

"PR complete" and "release by"

We generally talk about two dates when it comes to upcoming releases:

  • PR complete or "all PRs out by": this is the date when all pull requests that are intended to be part of the release should be functionally complete and out for review. It's OK if it still needs a few updates, but expectations on pending PRs should be that they'll wrap up within a business day or two. This is what's tracked in our sprints.
  • Release or "release by": This is roughly the "P95" estimate for the latest the publicly-available release packages are published and available under the assumption that the corresponding PR complete date holds. This is an estimate that's intended to be conservative -- most releases happen before the projected date, but release is always gated by readiness and it's possible for things to get postponed. Estimated release dates may be communicated to customers, but only with the clarification that it's a target and not a guarantee.

The single "source of truth" for the SDK's "PR complete" date is the sprint definition on Azure DevOps: https://msasg.visualstudio.com/Skyman/_sprints/taskboard/Carbon%20Team/Skyman/Carbon/

See the sprint date range definition in the upper right, e.g.:

"Release by" dates, meanwhile, are generally estimated at about two weeks past PR complete -- time enough for in-flight PRs to wrap up, release candidates to be built and validated across all languages/environments, documentation and other external repository resources to be staged, and bits to be published.

The dates here are replicated for convenience and history. This may not always be entirely up to date; please check the sprint board above or contact the team (cdev) if anything's unclear!

Release planning

SDK planning -- Wiki

Release signoff

SDK release process -- OneNote
citations.title: AI Cognitive Services SDK Releases

citations.content:
Customize your build for Embedded Speech

Embedded speech (recognition, synthesis) support is not enabled by default. To enable it, download and configure the following external components: * ONNX runtime * Download build artifacts as instructed in external\onnx_runtime\README.md.

  • SR runtime and models
  • Download build artifacts as instructed in external\sr_runtime\README.md.
  • Add -DEXTENSION_RNNT_ENABLED=true to Carbon cmake options to enable the feature.
  • It is not necessary to download all SR models if not specifically needed. cxx_api_tests uses FP\en-US\V4\onnx and whatever the latest FP\en-US\V#\onnx and FP\de-DE\V#\onnx models are (# = the highest version number available).
  • If running cxx_api_tests, add --offlineModelPathList=path\to\model(s) to command-line options.

  • Complete embedded SR tests require also embedded TTS, as well as KWS and GStreamer (see Customized extensions in this document).

  • TTS runtime and voices

  • Download build artifacts as instructed in external\offline_tts\README.md.

  • Add -DEXTENSION_HYBRID_TTS_ENABLED=true to Carbon cmake options to enable the feature.

  • 1DS C/C++ SDK libraries for embedded speech telemetry on Windows

  • Download build artifacts as instructed in external\cpp_client_telemetry_windows\README.md.

Customized extensions

Carbon builds a variety of optional extensions that aren't included in the build project by default. Each has a set of setup instructions, usually involving downloading a build artifact, and each has a cmake flag to enable it in your local build. The "source of truth" for these extensions is the CMakeLists.txt file in the root folder of your clone; search for "EXTENSION_" or "DEXTENSION". As a snap:

Extension Vision/Speech Build parameter Uses folders
KWS Speech -DEXTENSION_KWS_ENABLED="ON" Carbon\external\KWS (See README.md there)
Audio Compression
(Sending Silk audio to the cloud)		 Speech -DEXTENSION_AUDIOCOMPRESSION_ENABLED="ON" Carbon\source\extensions\audio-compression
(TODO is this still used? Carbon\external\silk-codec)
GStreamer decoder support
(Decoding compressed input audio)		 Speech -DEXTENSION_CODEC_ENABLED="ON" Carbon\source\extensions\codec
Carbon\external\gstreamer-android
Carbon\external\gstreamer-windows
Media source Vision -DEXTENSION_MEDIA_SOURCE_INGESTION_ENABLED="ON" carbon\external\media-source-ingestion

NOTE: See the instructions in each extension's folder, e.g. carbon/external/kws/readme.md, to ensure a successful local build.
citations.title: Checkout and Build Carbon on Windows

citations.content:
Speech & Vision CLI FAQ

How do I tag a CLI test to be "skipped"?

Add tag: skip to the test declaration/definition.

Example test not tagged with skip:

- area: image analyze
 tests:
 - laptop: image analyze --file @LAPTOP_ON_KITCHEN_TABLE_JPEG
 expect: |
 DESCRIPTION: .*laptop
 1 PERSON\(s\): person \(\d+x\d+ at \d+,\d+\)
 \d+ OBJECT\(s\):
 Laptop
 \d+ TAG\(s\): .*laptop

Example test tagged with skip:

 - area: image analyze
 tests:
 - laptop: image analyze --file @LAPTOP_ON_KITCHEN_TABLE_JPEG
 tag: skip
 expect: |
 DESCRIPTION: .*laptop
 1 PERSON\(s\): person \(\d+x\d+ at \d+,\d+\)
 \d+ OBJECT\(s\):
 Laptop
 \d+ TAG\(s\): .*laptop
citations.title: Speech & Vision CLI FAQ

citations.content:
Checkout and Build Carbon on Windows

Setup

Resource Notes
CMake Required https://cmake.org/download/ -- The cmake version should be >= 3.16. (You're best bet is to use teh same version that the ADO lab agents are using as you know that'll work see https://github.com/actions/runner-images/blob/main/images/win/Windows2022-Readme.md to find that version) Under "Binary distributions", click on the .msi file next to "Windows win64-x64 Installer". During installation, select "Add CMake to the system PATH for all users" or for "current user".
NuGet Required https://www.nuget.org/downloads -- Not an installer, so put nuget.exe somewhere on your system path (e.g. Windows\System32 from an admin command prompt)
Visual Studio 2022 Recommended https://visualstudio.microsoft.com -- You can use vscode or other environments as an IDE, but Visual Studio is the standard and a great place to start. Grab the Enterprise edition from . Include .NET desktop development, Desktop development with C++, and Python development as workloads, or run the Visual Studio Installer if you need to add these workloads to an existing install.
Recommended extension: StopOnFirstBuildError. The Carbon Visual Studio project has lots of solution in it. When you develop code using VS, sometimes you want the build to stop on the first build error. Otherwise, it will continue on to try and build all the solutions in the project. To install the extension, open Visual Studio 2022 (you can select "continue without code..."), Select Extension --> Manage Extensions --> Online, and search for StopOnFirstBuildError. Select and install it. This is a direct link to the VS marketplace page for this extension. Once the extension is installed, you will see a "Stop build on first error" check box in the VS build menu (only visible in a multi-project solution)
Python Required
(For Python)		 https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/ -- Install Python 3.x.x (be sure to pick the 64-bit version!)
Java Required
(for Java)		 https://www.azul.com/downloads/zulu -- In the section "Download Zulu Builds of OpenJDK" go to the latest build, find the Windows 64-bit row, and click on the .msi link. Install it in the default folder.
Add JAVA_HOME as a global environment variable. For example, if you install Zulu 15 using the default path, set the environment variable JAVA_HOME to C:\Program Files\zulu\zulu-15, if this wasn't done by the installer already. To set an environment variable, click on the Windows Start icon, start typing "environment" --> click on "edit environment variables for your account" --> "Environment Variables". Add/update the system variables as needed.

Quick checks (or troubleshooting)

From a fresh CLI environment (e.g. cmd.exe):

  • echo %JAVA_HOME% to confirm JAVA_HOME is on your PATH (see "Java," above)
  • cmake --version should work and report a version => 3.19.7
  • py should work (see "Python," above) -- Ctrl+Z exits the interactive prompt

  • javac should work (see "Java," above)Clone the repository

  • Create a local clone of the Carbon codebase with: shell git clone https://msasg.visualstudio.com/DefaultCollection/Skyman/_git/Carbon

    Here (and in the rest of the document) we assume that the source code is cloned into a subdirectory named Carbon. But you can select any name, by adding the target folder name at the end of the above git clone command.

    Although the Carbon repository is using submodules for several dependencies, it is not necessary to do a recursive clone. The CMAKE process in the following step will clone the required submodules into your local repository.
citations.title: Checkout and Build Carbon on Windows

citations.content:
Notes

  • If you get a build errors similar to D:\src\carbon\build\source\bindings\csharp\Microsoft.CognitiveServices.Speech.csharp.csproj : error NU1301: Unable to load the service index for source https://pkgs.dev.azure.com/msasg/skyman/_packaging/skyman_PublicPackages/nuget/v3/index.json, open a Poswer Shell terminal and run the following: iex "& { $(irm https://aka.ms/install-artifacts-credprovider.ps1) } -AddNetfx"

  • In case you change the carbon.h interface, make sure to update the CMakefile.txt for the swig layer to reflect any change in the generated files (generated files are added/removed). This is currently due to a cmake limitation that does not allow for wildcard specifications (at least for the jar generation part).

  • If you want to include the csharp project into the solution, edit source/bindings/csharp/CMakeLists.txt and change set(USECSPROJ TRUE) to be set(USECSPROJ FALSE), then run cmake again. Please don't check in the change.

  • If you see "error 9009" failures in the NuGet restore projects, it typically indicates that devenv.exe can't access NuGet.exe (you can check the full output to verify). Try moving it to an unprotected location in your system-wide PATH (e.g. C:\tools instead of C:\windows\system32)

  • If you see "error MSB4236: The SDK 'Microsoft.NET.Sdk' specified could not be found." as a build failure reason, see this SO answer

  • If you see "LNK2001 unresolved external symbol HTTPAPI_GetLastError Microsoft.CognitiveServices.Speech.core" trying to build in Visual Studio, run "git submodule update" from the CLI to sync to the latest Azure-C-Shared submodule

Back to Carbon main page page.
citations.title: Checkout and Build Carbon on Windows
